folder: St. Marks Place & Hyatt Street, Staten Island, NY
original_title: Richmond: St. Marks Place - Hyatt Street
text:
325 St. Marks Place, at the north-east corner of Hyatt Street, showing the J.C. Thompson House (1874). It later became known as the "Bella Vista" and was the home of Fred Tiedemann (1898) and, later (1907), that of Richard Agar. It was also the property of F. Ducasse (1917). P.L. Sperr states that it was the home of Wm. T. Davis in 1881, when the Natural Science Association of Staten Island was started here. Date owners' names appear.

1881

Copy by Wm. T. Davis of photograph taken in 1881, through P.L. Sperr

folder: St. Marks Place & Hyatt Street, Staten Island, NY
original_title: Richmond: St. Marks Place - Hyatt Street
text:
(1)
332 St. Marks Place, west side, at the head of Hyatt Street, showing the James Walsh residence. In 1898 the house
was owned by Mrs. E. W. Titus.
June 17, 1926
P. L. Sperr
(2)
The garden at the south side of the Walsh residence.
June 19, 1926
P. L. Sperr
(3)
The garden in the rear of the house. The
frame dwellings shown are numbers 14 to 20 Montgomery
Avenue.
June 17, 1926

folder: Hyatt Street & St. Marks Place, Staten Island, NY
original_title: Richmond: Hyatt Street - St. Marks Place
text:
(1)
Hyatt Street, west from Bay Street to St. Marks Place. In the right foreground is visible part of the Borough Hall, and in the left background is the St. George Branch of the New York Public Library.

March 1930

P. L. Sperr

(2)
The same, at a later date. The new building, on the right, is a branch of the Staten Island Savings Bank, 15 Hyatt Street, occupying the site of the two dwellings seen directly to the left of the Borough Hall in view 1.

May 26, 1937

P. L. Sperr

folder: St. Marks Place & Hyatt Street, Staten Island, NY
original_title: Richmond: St. Marks Place - Hyatt Street
text:
332 St. Marks Place, west side, at the head of Hyatt Street, showing the former James Walsh house after taxpayers have been erected in front of it. On the right is the Brighton Heights Reformed Church.

June 13, 1937

P. L. Sperr
